issue.title: Allow a custom Attribute to generate a Definition instance
issue.body:
# Custom Attributes

Annotated Container should support applications providing their own custom Attribute.

## Problem

It is often the case an app will include an object or class in the container that acts as a shared service but is not a "Service" in the semantic sense of the word. For example, a `Controller` or `Repository` instance. The Container may need to be responsible for constructing these objects and ensuring a single instance is shared they aren't really a Service. Typically, you'd expect these types of interfaces to be more restricted in what application layers they can be used, unlike a Service.

It would be useful if the application could define a custom Attribute and how it gets mapped to a corresponding Definition. For example, this would allow an attribute like `#[Controller]` or `#[Repository]` that provides similar functionality as a shared service but with more semantics. Additionally, future static analysis tools built around Annotated Container could detect when implementations cross into app layers they shouldn't be aware of.

## Solution

This section is still a rough draft. More thought has to be given how to do this:

- Make Attributes implement an interface and change our Attribute gathering to check for instances of this interface instead of the Attribute directly
- Introduce a way for apps to define factories for turning an Attribute into a Definition

issue.title: Reconsider JSON serialization format
issue.body:
It would be helpful to support functionality out-of-the-box that is currently not easily accomplished. The `Psr\Log\LoggerAwareInterface` is a type that should be able to be prepared without registering as an explicit service. This is currently not possible. If you want to prepare this type you MUST also define it as an explicit service.

 It is unlikely that you'd actually want to get an instance of a `LoggerAwareInterface` from a Container and having this in the container as a service seems off. We should consider how the serializer formats itself to not have this requirement.
